subdebateinfo.title: Mitochondrial Donation Law Reform (Maeve's Law) Bill 2021

p.span: Mitochondrial Donation Law Reform (Maeve's Law) Bill 2021
In Committee
Consideration resumed.
The CHAIR (21:05): The committee is considering the Mitochondrial Donation Law Reform (Maeve's Law) Bill 2021 and amendments (1) to (9) on sheet 1518, moved by Senator Canavan.

Senator O'SULLIVAN (Western Australia) (21:05): So we're up to date with what we're dealing with here, colleagues, these are the amendments that were moved by Senator Canavan, but in his absence I will speak briefly on them. This deals with the two techniques that the bill proposes and effectively removes one of those techniques, still allowing the research and the procedures to go forward but in a limited way.

The techniques for mitochondrial donation, for example the pro-nuclear transfer technique, result in the creation of two zygotes or embryos. The zygote that is left with defective mitochondria is then discarded. This raises, of course, the ethical issue of the creation of life—that is, a zygote—as a tool or instrument to help another life. This life is created with the knowledge that it will be destroyed. The Australian Catholic Bishops Conference said about these techniques:

… the disposing of any human embryos because such actions would instrumentalise human embryos, treating them as part of a production process where they can be kept or disposed of subject to arbitrary judgements.
These amendments deal with that technique that involves the transfer of mitochondria after the creation of an embryo so as to not create embryos for destruction.

These amendments remove the pro-nuclear transfer and second polar body transfer techniques as approved methods. If these amendments pass, the research and clinical practice will continue—so, if you vote for this amendment, it doesn't mean that you're voting against the research in this field—but they do deal with the pro-life aspect of the technique that some might have some ethical issues with. The amendments deal with the techniques that transfer mitochondria between the prospective mother's and donor's eggs before the creation of life. These techniques, as I said, avoid the ethical controversy over whether a human life should be created simply as a tool to help another life.

Some argue that the embryonic methods have shown more chance of success and, therefore, if we removed them from the bill, we would materially reduce the chance of a successful mitochondrial donation occurring. That's not correct. A recent report in the Annual Review of Genomics and Human Genetics medical journal found that there had been three births, one in Mexico, one in Greece and one in Ukraine, using the techniques permitted by this bill. Two of these live births used the techniques that actually do not destroy embryos, so two-thirds would still be permitted if this amendment were to go through. Two-thirds of the births so far have used pro-life techniques. Only one of these births was performed for mitochondrial donation—the others were transferring material to overcome some fertility issues—and that birth used a method that does not destroy the embryo. So there's no evidence that these amendments would restrict the development of mitochondrial donation services, given the evidence that pro-life, non-destructive techniques can work.

So, colleagues, if you support research in this field you can actually vote for this and that research would be able to continue. But if you do have ethical issues with the use of embryos that, by their creation and design, are ultimately to be destroyed then this amendment would eliminate the possibility and remove that as an option as far as the research and use of these techniques go. I encourage you to support this amendment.

Senator O'NEILL (New South Wales) (21:10): I would like to associate myself with the remarks just put on the record by Senator O'Sullivan. I also want to acknowledge Senator Canavan in moving this amendment. For those who might be listening and just picking up the debate—and perhaps for senators who are here at this late hour and hoping that it won't be too late an hour by the time we depart—I just want to make some general remarks about the nature of this debate.

This is a debate that is informed by conscience. Happily, we live in Australia, where there's the freedom to practice our religion—although we have recently been unable to pass through this parliament legislation to prevent discrimination against people of faith. Nonetheless, I'm a senator from the Australian Labor Party and it was determined by our caucus that this matter would be a free vote on conscience. My conscience on these matters that we're debating about the sanctity of human life are informed by the great theological tradition and the language, practices and beliefs of the Catholic faith. That is only one faith among many. There are many people of other faiths who share the views that I'm going to express with my vote today in support of the arguments that were just put so cogently and succinctly by Senator O'Sullivan. But there are people of no faith who also share these views about the protection of human life and embryos. That is why this is such an important vote and debate.

I am very appreciative of my Labor colleagues and the Labor caucus in making sure that this evening, although there could have been the option considered to truncate the debate and to guillotine the debate, we are going to be allowed to debate long into the night, although that is not my intention. We will actually prosecute this, I hope, quite efficiently, because I think we know where it's going to land. Nonetheless, it's important for this parliament to preserve the right of people of faith to exercise their conscience in matters of life in particular. That's why this particular amendment is one I wholly endorse and support. I hope that those who hold that worldview, whether it's informed by faith or another form of morality and decision-making in their own life, will also support Senator Canavan's amendment that's up for discussion right now.

Senator KENEALLY (New South Wales—Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate) (21:13): I don't wish to prolong the debate; I just want to make a very short contribution to indicate my support for the amendments and to associate myself with the remarks of Senator O'Neill. I think it's incredibly important that we have this debate as a debate, not as a guillotine, and acknowledge that that's what the Senate has achieved tonight. I join myself with Senator O'Neill in acknowledging that we do not want to prolong this debate. I think it's important to recognise that, throughout, this debate has been conducted respectfully.

While I won't belabour the point, if the Senate would just indulge me for a moment: this is my last day in the Senate, of course, and I will be contesting for the House of Representatives. I just want a moment for a personal reflection, to say that Senator O'Neill and I first met in 2002 when we both first stood as state candidates in a state election. I find it quite nice almost 20 years later to be standing here with her because the thing we had in common from that point was a passion for the Labor Party and a passion for the Catholic social justice principles and ensuring that people of faith had a voice in our party. So I'm very proud tonight to associate myself with her after the 20 years we've spent working together, and I look forward to doing it in, hopefully, a Labor government.

More to the point, I think it is important that we have these debates. I think it's important that these views be put. Based on the numbers, I acknowledge that there are some people who are not able to be here tonight to vote in the way they did a few weeks ago, due to illness and other reasons, and perhaps in a moment Senator O'Neill might want to acknowledge our colleague Senator Kitching, who would have made a contribution and would have voted in this debate. I want to thank Senator O'Sullivan for taking on Senator Canavan's amendments and making sure that we have the opportunity to express our views on them.

Senator SCARR (Queensland) (21:15): I did haven't the benefit of being here when the Mitochondrial Donation Law Reform (Maeve's Law) Bill 2021 was discussed, due to a close family member having COVID, which meant I had to be in isolation. Firstly, I say to my colleagues in the chamber that I watched the debate very carefully from afar, and I was extraordinarily impressed with the decency and respect with which the arguments were prosecuted. I have struggled with this bill in many respects. I have sought to try and convince myself to vote for the bill unamended, but, at the end of the day, I simply struggle on an ethical basis—not informed by any religious perspective—with the notion that one should create an embryo with the intention that part of it will be transferred and the balance destroyed. Hence I feel obliged, as a matter of conscience, to support this amendment. In particular I must say, Senator Keneally, I listened to your contributions very carefully during the last sitting and I found your arguments extraordinarily convincing.
The CHAIR: The question is that amendments (1) to (7) be agreed to.
The CHAIR (21:24): I will move to the second part of that amendment. The question is that sections 7D and 7G in item 20 of schedule 1 stand as printed.
Question agreed to.
Senator O'NEILL (New South Wales) (21:24): I move amendment (1) on sheet 1541, which opposes schedule 1 in the following terms:
(1) Schedule 1, item 103, page 56 (line 24) to page 57 (line 10), section 47A to be opposed.

This is simply a small amendment that seeks to prevent immunity from civil action. Of course, we are debating quite a significant change to the law, and we've been discussing during some of these divisions the creeping nature of this piece of legislation, which 20 years ago we were unwilling to introduce. I see in the chamber senators who were on the committee with me when we undertook this inquiry and who understand the portent of what we're undertaking tonight. Ultimately, history will reveal what it is that we have done, and I have fears and concerns, and that's why I am putting these amendments: to provide a degree of protection that I think we should be cautiously advancing with. This particular amendment, which I urge you to support, concerns an immunity from civil actions that I don't think researchers should be protected from. If this is such great and un-risky technology, then there should be no protection. Thank you.
The CHAIR: The question is that schedule 1 stand as printed.
Senator O'NEILL (New South Wales) (21:31): by leave—I move opposition amendments (1) to (3) on sheet 1576 together:
(1) Schedule 1, item 17, page 19 (after line 8), at the end of subsection 28J(3), add:

; (e) if the application is for a clinical practice research and training licence, or a clinical practice licence, relating to a particular mitochondrial donation technique—all clinical data published by the Government of the United Kingdom relating to that technique.
(2) Schedule 1, item 17, page 34 (after line 11), at the end of Division 4A, add:
(1) The NHMRC Licensing Committee must, within 1 month after the end of each reporting period, give the Minister a report in accordance with subsection (2).
(2) The report must include the following de-identified information in relation to the reporting period:
(a) the number of each kind of mitochondrial donation licence issued under section 28J; and
(b) the outcomes of the activities carried out under each licence issued under section 28J, including:
(i) the number of births of children as a result of pregnancies achieved using a mitochondrial donation technique under a clinical trial licence or a clinical practice licence; and
(ii) the number of adverse events notified to the NHMRC Licensing Committee under paragraph 28S(3)(a).
(3) The Minister must table a copy of the report in each House of the Parliament within 10 sitting days of that House after receiving the report.
(4) For the purposes of this section:
(a) each of the following periods is a reporting period:
(i) the period of 12 months beginning on the day this section commences; and
(ii) each subsequent period of 12 months; and
(b) information is de-identified if the information is no longer about an identifiable individual or an individual who is reasonably identifiable.
(3) Schedule 1, item 55A, page 47 (lines 10 to 22), to be opposed.

The last couple of amendments that we've considered are ones that really do go to a matter of conscience. I ask those who, to date, have made up their minds on their conscience just to look at this as legislators. This is more of a technical amendment, in my view, and I hope that you might be persuaded by the argument that mitochondrial donation research in the UK was, in fact, legalised in 2015. It began in one laboratory in Newcastle in 2016 and at this point of time, after six years of research, as we make this very important decision, there is absolutely no data available to Australians. That is very, very concerning to me.

We don't know whether experiments have happened. We don't know what the experiments produced. We don't know, in fact, if there are any pregnancies, despite the hope that is held out. We don't know if there have been any live births. We don't know if there have been any unexpected difficulties or challenges. None of that has been made available to inform our decisions here. As the Australian mito bill is broadly modelled on the UK law, and as we are doing this on the back of reported success that is unobservable, it's reasonable, I believe, to expect that the results of the UK experiments would, at the very least, be available to the NHMRC's Embryo Research Licensing Committee.

This amendment not only advances a position that I hold but supports the work of Senator Canavan to introduce stronger and more frequent reporting guidelines for this technology. Senators, whatever your conscience may tell you, I would put to you that this is just sensible legislative caution that requires our best attention, because this is about getting the facts on the record using the facts and the evidence from the only other jurisdiction that has advanced this piece of technology. So I seek your support for this amendment.

Senator STOKER (Queensland—Assistant Minister to the Attorney-General, Assistant Minister for Women and Assistant Minister for Industrial Relations) (21:34): I wonder if I might direct a question to Senator O'Neill to help us understand the import of this amendment. Is the purpose of it to ensure that any Australian research is made available and transparent, or is the purpose of the amendment to provide some sort of requirement for the British data to be made available?

The reason I ask is that it seems to me that we don't have the authority to require that certain information of a foreign government's health bodies be provided. If, however, it were to be structured in such a way that it were more directed at our own decision to be transparent about the way that we reported this data, then I would have thought it's both within power and something worth doing. So, if you could help me understand that, I would appreciate it very much.

Senator O'NEILL (New South Wales) (21:35): In fusing the two pieces from Senator Canavan and me together in this amendment, it requests that UK data be made available to the NHMRC. It also seeks to encourage the Australian data to be made available because, currently, this is incredibly opaque.

Senator STOKER (Queensland—Assistant Minister to the Attorney-General, Assistant Minister for Women and Assistant Minister for Industrial Relations) (21:35): Just so that I understand this fully: does that mean that the failure of British authorities to provide information in response to that request would provide some barrier to the ability of research in Australia to proceed? Or would a request not met fall away, in a sense?

Senator O'NEILL (New South Wales) (21:35): As I understand it, this would require the NHMRC to access that data from the UK and, given the closeness of the association in the way in which that has been integrated at the moment, I believe that it would not be an impediment.
The CHAIR: The question is that amendments (1) and (2) be agreed to.
The CHAIR (21:40): The question now is that, in regard to opposition amendment (3) on sheet 1576, item 55A of schedule 1 stand as printed.

Senator O'NEILL (New South Wales) (21:44): Before I move the next amendment, I would like to indicate that there are a number of senators who were highly engaged in this debate previously who are unable to be here. Senator Canavan I think I acknowledged earlier on, because he was very instrumental, but there was Senator Duniam, Senator Farrell, Senator Fierravanti-Wells and, of course, Senator Polley, Senator Sterle and, most sadly, Senator Kitching. And I want to acknowledge, from the Labor team, that there was an arrangement to make sure that her vote counted and that an arrangement was made to honour her particular voting pattern. So I thank my colleagues for that.

Finally, if I can, I will just make the general point that, while the government failed to get the bill against religious discrimination through, it has chosen to bring this particular, very contentious bill to the Senate this evening. It's really one minute to midnight, and here we are discussing an issue of great importance to Australians, particularly Australians of faith. But, as Senator Scarr has indicated, you don't have to have a particular faith position to hold a humanist view and to vote for the amendments that I'm putting forward.
I move amendment (1) on sheet 1574:
(1) Schedule 1, item 17, page 26 (after line 11), after paragraph 28P(4)(e), insert:
(ea) that:
(i) a test for compatibility between the woman's genome and the donor's genome has been conducted; and
(ii) the results of the test establish that the woman's genome is compatible with the donor's genome; and

This amendment calls for a clear and unambiguous measure of a successful test of compatibility before approval is granted. It will minimise the potential transmission of mito disease from the mother to the child, and there is recent research that shows strong evidence from large human population samples that mitochondrial and nuclear genomes are under selective pressure for compatibility, so those from eggs from different women can't be safely mixed and matched without impunity. The amendment is a response to that recent research. It's a measure to ensure efficacy of this experimental technology, for the safety of both the mother and the child. I urge senators to support the amendment.

Senator BIRMINGHAM (South Australia—Minister for Finance, Leader of the Government in the Senate and Vice-President of the Executive Council) (21:46): I'll speak very briefly on this. I would indicate and encourage opposition to this amendment. I'm advised that there's no known test in relation to the type of genome compatibility that this amendment would seek to require between two people in the way in which it is presented, and it's not clear how the requirement could in fact be adhered to in the context in which this amendment is put forward.

I understand the intent of what Senator O'Neill is seeking to achieve, but, in terms of the first phase of operations under this act, under the trial periods, this would be an amendment that potentially would have adverse consequences for the ability of the bill to achieve its objectives were it to pass into law.
The CHAIR: The question is that amendment (1) on sheet 1574 as moved by Senator O'Neill be agreed to.
Senator O'NEILL (New South Wales) (21:51): by leave—I move amendments (1) to (11) on sheet 1578 together:
(1) Schedule 1, item 19, page 36 (before line 1), before the definition of first polar body transfer in section 5, insert:
affected mitochondria: a woman has affected mitochondria if inheriting the mitochondria would predispose the offspring of the woman to mitochondrial disease.
(2) Schedule 1, item 20, page 37 (line 7), after "a woman", insert "with affected mitochondria".
(3) Schedule 1, item 20, page 37 (line 9), omit "different woman", substitute "woman without affected mitochondria".
(4) Schedule 1, item 20, page 37 (line 18), after "a woman", insert "with affected mitochondria".
(5) Schedule 1, item 20, page 37 (lines 21 to 22), omit "different woman", substitute "woman without affected mitochondria".
(6) Schedule 1, item 20, page 38 (line 10), after "a woman", insert "with affected mitochondria".
(7) Schedule 1, item 20, page 38 (line 12), omit "different woman", substitute "woman without affected mitochondria".
(8) Schedule 1, item 20, page 38 (line 23), after "a woman", insert "with affected mitochondria".
(9) Schedule 1, item 20, page 38 (line 25), omit "different woman", substitute "woman without affected mitochondria".
(10) Schedule 1, item 20, page 39 (line 1), after "a woman", insert "with affected mitochondria".
(11) Schedule 1, item 20, page 39 (lines 3 to 4), omit "different woman", substitute "woman without affected mitochondria".

This amendment seeks to explicitly and unequivocally specify that mitochondrial techniques are solely licensed to be used for transfers between the egg or a zygote of a woman who is suffering mito disease to the egg or a zygote of a healthy woman. It would seem obvious that it's implied in the name of the legislation but, in reality, clarity is required. I would urge you to support this amendment, because it is essential. There is a great likelihood that some IVF clinics in other jurisdictions who claim to have used mitochondrial transfer techniques have used that to treat general infertility, especially in older women whose eggs are necessarily older. This seeks to be very explicit that this procedure is solely for the use of response to mitochondrial disease.

Senator BIRMINGHAM (South Australia—Minister for Finance, Leader of the Government in the Senate and Vice-President of the Executive Council) (21:52): Chair, I'm advised that this amendment is in fact a less stringent limitation in terms of requirements than the bill already provides for that, before a mitochondrial donation technique can be used under the bill, the trial participant or patient must be approved by the NHMRC licensing committee under new section 28P of the Research Involving Human Embryos Act 2002. An approval can only be granted if, among other things, under paragraphs 28P(4)(a) and (b), the trial participant or patient has a particular risk of their offspring inheriting mitochondria that would predispose them to mitochondrial disease and there is a significant risk that mitochondrial disease that would develop would result in a serious illness or other serious medical condition. The existing provisions in the bill are more stringent, indeed, than this which would provide potentially a less stringent limitation or an element of confusion to the bill. With that, I would encourage the Senate to oppose the proposed amendment.
The CHAIR: The question is that amendments (1) to (11) on sheet 1578 moved by leave by Senator O'Neill be agreed to.
Senator O'NEILL (New South Wales) (21:57): by leave—I move amendments (1) and (2) on sheet 1575 together:
(1) Schedule 1, item 20, page 39 (after line 15), at the end of section 7H, add:
; (c) the Australian Code for the Responsible Conduct of Research.
(2) Schedule 1, page 59 (after line 28), after item 107, insert:
Insert:

Australian Code for the Responsible Conduct of Research means the Australian Code for the Responsible Conduct of Research, issued by the CEO of the NHMRC under the National Health and Medical Research Council Act 1992, as existing from time to time.
Note: The Australian Code for the Responsible Conduct of Research could in 2022 be viewed on the website of the NHMRC (https://www.nhmrc.gov.au).

I believe this is simply an oversight in the legislation. The bill currently requires those who engage in mitochondrial research to comply with the National Statement on Ethical Conduct in Human Research, but it does not require compliance with the Australian Code for the Responsible Conduct of Research. However, both are referenced in the government's explanation of how clinical trials work. This amendment simply seeks to rectify that oversight. I know some senators are concerned that this would prevent the bill from proceeding at all. It is clear that the House is sitting tomorrow and, if the bill were to be returned there with these amendments if they are passed, that would give sufficient time for the House to complete the process. I seek senators' support.

Senator BIRMINGHAM (South Australia—Minister for Finance, Leader of the Government in the Senate and Vice-President of the Executive Council) (21:58): The Australian Code for the Responsible Conduct of Research is a short principles based document that articulates the broad principles and responsibilities that underpin the conduct of Australian research. It was developed jointly by the NHMRC, the Australian Research Council and Universities Australia. Adherence to the code is actually a prerequisite for the receipt of funding from the NHMRC or the ARC. Given its prerequisite nature in that regard and the nature of the code itself, these amendments are not considered necessary to the operation of the bill or to ensuring that any who operate under the bill would be adhering to the code.
The CHAIR: The question is that amendments (1) and (2) on sheet 1575, as moved by Senator O'Neill, be agreed to.
Senator O'NEILL (New South Wales) (22:02): I move amendment (1) on sheet 1577:
(1) Schedule 1, item 103, page 57 (after line 10), after section 47A, insert:
(1) This section applies in relation to a person if:
(a) both of the following apply:
(i) the person is a trial participant or a patient;
(ii) a child is born with a diagnosis at birth of mitochondrial disease in connection with a pregnancy achieved in the person as a result of using a mitochondrial donation technique; or
(b) both of the following apply:
(i) the person is a child of a trial participant;
(ii) the person is diagnosed at any time with mitochondrial disease.
(2) The person is entitled to be paid by the Commonwealth compensation in respect of loss, damage or injury of any kind suffered by the person as a result of the diagnosis of mitochondrial disease.
(3) Compensation under this section is to be paid out of money appropriated by the Parliament for this purpose.

It strikes me, as I stand here in this seat where we commenced the week and I struggled to hold my composure and honour Senator Kitching, that I asked for this place to create a living legacy to her memory and that we might find a way to agree and disagree more respectfully. It's a little ironic that, as much as I despair that we're doing a conscience vote at 10 o'clock in a rather expedited way, I have to observe the nature of the conversation this evening around the room and the respectful nature of the debate—basically, because nobody's arguing. We've actually ended a very fractious period with a little bit of the way in which people might hope we operate in the future. I am proud to stand here with you as senators, and I also want to very much thank those who have supported the amendments that I've put forward, even though we knew pretty well that we were going to go down in the count. This is a reflection that there are a range of views across the Australian people. We reflect that in what we bring here, and it is, I think, a signature that we bring our perspectives across party lines to represent Australians in the best way that we can. I appreciate the opportunity for this debate and I thank you at this late hour for remaining to allow me to advance these amendments. This is the last one. You can cheer now.

This is a bill that acknowledges that adverse events are a potential outcome if this legislation is passed. It's an experimental technology, as I said earlier. There is only one other country that is actually operating under the auspices of a piece of legislation that allows this kind of research to go on, and it remains the case today, as we make our decision here this evening, that we do not know. We don't know if there have been successes or failures. We do not know if there have been aberrant results. We don't know anything after six years in the UK. And there are risks embedded in this technology.

This amendment seeks to establish a federal government compensation fund or a similar mechanism to support any child born with mito disease as a result of the practices that this bill would license. I seek your support for that amendment, Senators.

Senator BIRMINGHAM (South Australia—Minister for Finance, Leader of the Government in the Senate and Vice-President of the Executive Council) (22:05): I thank Senator O'Neill for the observations that she made before in relation to the conduct of this debate. They're observations that I think I made at an earlier stage, particularly following the very extensive second reading contributions that were made around the chamber. Debates of this nature do tend to bring out the best of parliamentary contributions, and this bill is a bill that does present, on the one hand, the challenge of considering the impacts of medical conditions that have terrible consequences on families and children, and the intent of the bill is to seek to avoid those terrible consequences. Equally, it is a bill that presents ethical challenges and considerations in the construct of the bill and the theories and approaches that are being applied, and I know that, across the chamber, whichever way senators are voting, they have wrestled in their own way with those ethical considerations, weighing them against the objectives of the bill to help to ultimately save the lives of children and provide improved medical outcomes.

Senator O'Neill, in relation to the final amendment that you have moved, which seeks to create a compensation scheme, this is a somewhat challenging amendment that you present on the basis that the whole point of the bill and the donation techniques is to seek to reduce the risk of transmission of mitochondrial disease. If mitochondrial disease were to be passed on despite the techniques, then, depending on the severity of the disease, the types of supports that would ordinarily have been available to parents and families in those circumstances would be available, of course, through the health system. Were there to be instances of any evidence of medical negligence or otherwise, then the normal avenues would be available. But it is a bill that is seeking very much to ensure informed consent and knowledge and, as we stepped through earlier, the two-stage approach, in terms of the very extensive trial stage before moving into a clinical phase.

The amendment also, in its composition, has some anomalous outcomes, in terms of compensation being limited to diagnosis when a child is born, at birth, whereas symptoms are sometimes only evident at a later stage. Compensation also is limited to mothers, which may not always be relevant in that regard, and there are areas in which it would deny compensation at the clinical practice stage, even though we're providing for it at the trial stage. I don't believe this amendment would aid in terms of the composition of the bill. I would encourage the amendment to be defeated, but I do very much again thank Senator O'Neill for her thoughtful contributions in the debate, as I do all senators for the way in which they engaged during the debate.
The CHAIR: The question is that amendment (1) on sheet 1577, as moved by Senator O'Neill, be agreed to.

body.p:
Question negatived.
Bill agreed to.
Bill reported without amendments; report adopted.

p.span: Third Reading
Senator BIRMINGHAM (South Australia—Minister for Finance, Leader of the Government in the Senate and Vice-President of the Executive Council) (22:12): I move:
That this bill be now read a third time.
The PRESIDENT: The question is that the third reading be agreed to.

body.p:
Question agreed to.
Bill read a third time.

subdebateinfo.title: Migration Amendment (Strengthening the Character Test) Bill 2021

p.span: Migration Amendment (Strengthening the Character Test) Bill 2021
First Reading
Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Senator BIRMINGHAM (South Australia—Minister for Finance, Leader of the Government in the Senate and Vice-President of the Executive Council) (22:23): I move:
That this bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.
Question agreed to.
Bill read a first time.
Second Reading
Senator BIRMINGHAM (South Australia—Minister for Finance, Leader of the Government in the Senate and Vice-President of the Executive Council) (22:23): I move:
That this bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
If non-citizens do not abide by the law, or they pose a risk to the safety and good order of the community, the Government can and should prevent the entry and stay of such individuals.

The Migration Amendment (Strengthening the Character Test) Bill 2021 strengthens the character test in section 501 of the Migration Act 1958 by providing a new specific and objective ground to consider visa refusal or cancellation where a non-citizen has been convicted of certain serious criminal offences—called 'designated offences' in the Bill—regardless of the length of sentence imposed.

At present, not all non-citizens convicted of serious criminal offences objectively fail the character test. Certain criminal offences against Australian or foreign laws may involve violence against a person and have a significant impact on victims—nevertheless, the perpetrator may receive a sentence of less than 12 months for their crimes.

The Bill sends a clear message that the Australian community has no tolerance for non-citizens who have been convicted of such crimes. The amendments in the Bill will ensure the character test aligns directly with community expectations that non-citizens who are convicted of offences will not be permitted to enter or remain in the Australian community.

By strengthening the character test in this way, I and my delegates will have a clear and objective ground with which to consider cancelling the visa of, or refusing to grant a visa to, a non-citizen who has been convicted of a 'designated offence', regardless of the length of the sentence imposed.
A 'designated offence' is defined as an offence committed in Australia or in a foreign country, which is punishable by at least a maximum sentence of two years' imprisonment and involves:
violence, or a threat of violence, against a person; or
non-consensual conduct of a sexual nature; or
breaching an order made by a court or tribunal for the personal protection of another person; or
using or possessing a weapon; or
procuring, or assisting in any way with the commission of one of these designated offences.

The Bill also provides that, for an offence with one or more physical elements that involve violence against a person, a person's conviction for an offence of common assault (or equivalent) will not be taken to be a conviction for a designated offence, unless the act constituting the offence:
causes or substantially contributes—temporarily or permanently—to bodily harm to another person or harm to another person's mental health; or
involves family violence.

This will ensure that low-level offending is not captured. However, any offence of common assault that involves family violence will be taken to be a designated offence regardless of whether the offence causes bodily harm or harm to a person's mental health. This aligns with the Government's position on combatting family violence.

The amendments in this Bill do not change the framework within which the character cancellation powers function. This new ground does not enliven mandatory cancellation powers. The amendments only seek to provide an additional, objective ground to consider refusing or cancelling a visa. The decision to refuse or cancel a visa using this ground will be discretionary.

Decision-makers exercising the discretion to refuse or cancel a person's visa are guided by comprehensive policy guidelines and Ministerial Directions, and take into account the individual's circumstances and relevant international obligations.
This means any decision to refuse or cancel a visa is a proportionate response to the individual circumstances of each case.
In summary, this Bill sends a clear and unequivocal message on behalf of the Australian community—that entry or stay in Australia is a privilege, granted only to those of good character.
I should add that we've been here before and we'll be here again and again until the Opposition stops blocking the Government's measures to deport dangerous foreign criminals.
Entry and stay in Australia is a privilege, not a right.
Labor is yet to convincingly explain why they oppose these laws.
However, through this Bill the Government will be giving them another opportunity to do so.
I commend this Bill to the Chamber.
Debate adjourned.

subdebateinfo.title: Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment (Enhanced Family Support) Bill 2022

p.span: Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment (Enhanced Family Support) Bill 2022
First Reading
Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Senator BIRMINGHAM (South Australia—Minister for Finance, Leader of the Government in the Senate and Vice-President of the Executive Council) (22:24): I move:
That this bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.
Question agreed to.
Bill read a first time.
Second Reading
Senator BIRMINGHAM (South Australia—Minister for Finance, Leader of the Government in the Senate and Vice-President of the Executive Council) (22:24): I move:
That this bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.

One of the great privileges of being the Minister for Veterans' Affairs and Defence Personnel is having the opportunity to meet, and get to know, so many of the men and women who serve and have served this nation and their incredible, supportive families.
I have seen first-hand the critical and fundamental role that families play in supporting the capability of our defence force and the wellbeing of defence members.
If we want a strong defence force—operating at its best—then we need to have the best possible support available for family members.

The responsibility to care for the men and women of the ADF, veterans and their families currently rests with our generation, and we have to do everything we can to give them the care and treatment they deserve.
The Australian Government recognises the unique challenges faced by these families.
Supporting the partners and children of our service personnel must be an ongoing and evolving effort.
This legislation that I am introducing today will expand the existing Family Support Package first introduced by the Australian Government in 2018.

This Bill demonstrates the Government's ongoing commitment to its response to Recommendation 19 of the Final Report of the Senate Inquiry into Suicide by Veterans and Ex-Service Personnel, The Constant Battle: Suicide by Veterans tabled in Parliament on 15 August 2017.
It also responds to recommendation 19.2 of the Productivity Commission Report A Better Way to Support Veterans to ensure veterans and their families are supported to the best of our ability.
Important new support to veterans in this Bill goes beyond a 2021-22 Budget measure and commences on 1 July 2022.

This initiative builds on and enhances the existing Family Support Package by expanding the services available and allowing families greater choice in how they use services provided through the program.
The Enhanced Family Support Package will also be available to more working age veteran families through expanded eligibility.

Intensive support will become available to families—at, or in crisis—to adjust to new or challenging life circumstances, complementing other Department of Veterans' Affairs and Australian Government services.
This initiative will provide families of veterans under 65 years that are in—or at risk of, being in—crisis with up to $12,500 over two years.
This support can be spent on a range of services that meet their health and wellbeing needs.
This includes household services such as cleaning, gardening, counselling for family members and a range of other practical support.
Families will be able to access up to $7,500 of support in the first year, and up to $5,000 in the second year.

In addition, families with children will be able to access a further $10,000 a year for each child under school age and $5,000 a year for each primary school aged child, until the child reaches high school age.
We know that widows and widowers are particularly vulnerable following the death of their veteran partners.
Under this initiative, the Family Support package for widows and widowers will be expanded to all three Acts that support veterans.
This package provides widowed partners under 65 years old up to $27,835 each year for two years.
This equates to $514.12 per week.
This support will help meet the cost of help around the home such as cleaning, gardening, maintenance and other practical services to support the family's wellbeing.
Widows and widowers will also have access to the additional child care assistance until their child reaches high school age.
To implement the Australian Government's Enhanced Family Support Package, Schedule 1 of the Bill will amend the Military Rehabilitation and Compensation Act 2004 to expand the Family Support Package.

It will also introduce a legislative framework to establish the Family Support Package in the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986 and the Safety, Rehabilitation and Compensation (Defence-related Claims) Act 1988.
This government is committed to supporting veterans and their families.
We want our servicemen and women, veterans and their families to know that Australia is proud of them and that our country will always be there for them.
I commend the Bill to the Chamber.
Ordered that further consideration of the second reading of this bill be adjourned to the first sitting day of the next period of sittings, 9 May 2022, in accordance with standing order 111.
BUSINESS
Days and Hours of Meeting
Senator BIRMINGHAM (South Australia—Minister for Finance, Leader of the Government in the Senate and Vice-President of the Executive Council) (22:25): I move:
That—

(a) the Senate, at its rising, adjourn till Monday, 9 May 2022, at 10 am, or such other time as may be fixed by the President or, in the event of the President being unavailable, by the Deputy President, and that the time of meeting so determined shall be notified to each senator; and
(b) leave of absence be granted to every member of the Senate from the end of the sitting today to the day on which the Senate next meets.
Question agreed to.
